question: Question 1-04/24/2012 A 1/M curve is being generated as fuel is loaded into the core. After some fuel elements have been loaded, the count rate existing at that time is taken to be the new initial count rate, C_0. Additional elements are then loaded and the inverse count rate ratio continues to decrease. As a result of changing the initial count rate:

answers.answer: a. criticality will occur with the same number of elements loaded as if there were no change in the initial count rate.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: b. criticality will occur earlier (i.e., with fewer elements loaded.)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF:UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

answers.answer: c. criticality will occur later (i.e., with more elements loaded.)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF:UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

answers.answer: d. criticality will be completely unpredictable.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF:UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

question: Question 2-04/24/2012 A reactor is critical at 18.1 inches on a controlling rod. The controlling rod is withdrawn to 18.4 inches. The reactivity inserted is 14.4 cents. What is the differential rod worth?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Control Rod Calibration. Δρ = 14.4 cents; Δx = 18.4 - 18.1 = 0.3 inches; Δρ/Δx = 48 cents/inch at the midpoint (18.25 inches).
Correct.
Incorrect. REF:UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Control Rod Calibration. Δρ = 14.4 cents; Δx = 18.4 - 18.1 = 0.3 inches; Δρ/Δx = 48 cents/inch at the midpoint (18.25 inches).

answers.answer: d. 14.4 cents/inch only between 18.1 and 18.4 inches.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF:UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Control Rod Calibration. Δρ = 14.4 cents; Δx = 18.4 - 18.1 = 0.3 inches; Δρ/Δx = 48 cents/inch at the midpoint (18.25 inches).

question: Question 3-04/24/2012 Two critical reactors at low power are identical except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0072 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0060. An equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors. Which ONE of the following will be the response of Reactor 2 compared to Reactor 1?

answers.answer: a. The resulting power level will be lower.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Equation Sheet. τ =(R*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λ_effρ]

answers.answer: b. The resulting power level will be higher.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. The resulting period will be longer.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Equation Sheet. τ =(R*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λ_effρ]

answers.answer: d. The resulting period will be shorter.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 4-04/24/2012 Which ONE of the following describes the response of the subcritical reactor to equal insertions of positive reactivity as the reactor approaches critical? Each reactivity insertion causes:

answers.answer: a. a SMALLER increase in the neutron flux, resulting in a LONGER time to reach equilibrium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

answers.answer: b. a LARGER increase in the neutron flux, resulting in a LONGER time to reach equilibrium.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. a SMALLER increase in the neutron flux, resulting in a SHORTER time to reach equilibrium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

answers.answer: d. a LARGER increase in the neutron flux, resulting in a SHORTER time to reach equilibrium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics IV, Critical Experiment.

question: Question 5-04/24/2012 During the neutron cycle from one generation to the next, several processes occur that may increase or decrease the available number of neutrons. Which ONE of the following factors describes an INCREASE in the number of neutrons during the cycle?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.
Correct
Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.
Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.

question: Question 6-04/24/2012 The effective neutron multiplication factor, K_eff, is defined as:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.
Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.
Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.
Correct

question: Question 7-04/24/2012 Which ONE of the following parameter changes will require control rod INSERTION to maintain constant power level following the change?

answers.answer: a. Removal of an experiment containing cadmium.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a void into the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Insertion of a control rod inserts negative reactivity to balance the positive reactivity added when removing a neutron absorber. All other answers add negative reactivity.
Incorrect. REF: Insertion of a control rod inserts negative reactivity to balance the positive reactivity added when removing a neutron absorber. All other answers add negative reactivity.

answers.answer: d. Buildup of samarium in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Insertion of a control rod inserts negative reactivity to balance the positive reactivity added when removing a neutron absorber. All other answers add negative reactivity.

question: Question 8-04/24/2012 Which ONE of the following is the time period during which the MAXIMUM amount of Xenon-135 will be present in the core?

answers.answer: a. 8 to 10 hours after a startup to 100% power.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.

answers.answer: b. 8 to 10 hours after shutdown from 100% power.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. 4 to 6 hours after a power decrease from 100% to 50%.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.

answers.answer: d. 4 to 6 hours after a power increase from 50% to 100%.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics I.

question: Question 9-04/24/2012 The reactor is operating in the automatic mode at 50% power. A problem in the secondary cooling system causes the primary coolant temperature to increase by 5 degrees F. Given that the primary coolant temperature coefficient is 7.0x10^-5 Δ k/k/deg. F and the differential rod worth of the regulating rod is 8.75x10^-5 Δk/k/inch, the change in the position of the regulating rod will be:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. Since coolant temperature increased, negative reactivity was added. Therefore, the rod must add positive reactivity, i.e. withdraw. (5 deg. F)x(7x10^-5 delta k/k/deg. F) / (8.75x10^-5 delta k/k/inch) = 4 inches.

Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. Since coolant temperature increased, negative reactivity was added. Therefore, the rod must add positive reactivity, i.e. withdraw. (5 deg. F)x(7x10^-5 delta k/k/deg. F) / (8.75x10^-5 delta k/k/inch) = 4 inches.
Correct

Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. Since coolant temperature increased, negative reactivity was added. Therefore, the rod must add positive reactivity, i.e. withdraw. (5 deg. F)x(7x10^-5 delta k/k/deg. F) / (8.75x10^-5 delta k/k/inch) = 4 inches.

question: Question 10-04/24/2012 Reactor period is at 26 seconds. How long will it take to increase power from 10 kilowatts to 100 kilowatts?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Math and Physics, p. 12
Correct
Incorrect. REF: Math and Physics, p. 12
Incorrect. REF: Math and Physics, p. 12

question: Question 11-04/24/2012 Which ONE of the following is an example of alpha (α) decay?

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Physics I, p. 23
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Physics I, p. 23
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Physics I, p. 23

question: Question 12-04/24/2012 K_eff for the reactor is 0.95. What is the shutdown margin for this condition? (I am NOT looking for Technical Specification definition)

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics II, p. 102
Correct
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics II, p. 102
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics II, p. 102

question: Question 13-04/24/2012 The reactor had a shutdown margin of 1.75% Δk/k, and a source range count rate of 15 counts per minute. After placing samples in the reactor the count rate increased to 30 counts per minute. What is the worth of the sample?

answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 14-04/24/2012 The main source of heat in the reactor one hour after shutdown is due to:

answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. Fission due to delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 113.

answers.answer: c. Spontaneous fission within the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 113.

answers.answer: d. Decay of radioactive structural materials
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 113.

question: Question 15-04/24/2012 For U^235, the thermal fission cross-section is 582 barns, and the capture cross-section is 99 barns. When a thermal neutron is absorbed by U^235, the probability that a fission will occur is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, p. 86 (Scope)
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, p. 86 (Scope)
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, p. 86 (Scope)
Correct

question: Question 16-04/24/2012 Which ONE of the following factors is the most significant in determining the differential worth of a control rod?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.
Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.
Correct

answers.answer: d. The amount of fuel in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.

question: Question 17-04/24/2012 When performing rod calibrations, many facilities pull the rod out a given increment, then measure the time for reactor power to double (doubling time), then calculate the reactor period. If the doubling time is 42 seconds, what is the reactor period?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 103
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 103
Correct
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, Reactor Physics III, p. 103

question: Question 19-04/24/2012 A reactor is subcritical with a K_eff of 0.955. A positive reactivity of 4.9% delta k/k is inserted into the core. At this point, the reactor is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. When keff = 0.955, ρ =-0.047 delta k/k; 4.9% delta k/k = + 0.049 delta k/k - 0.047 + 0.049 delta k/k = + 0.002 delta k/k, therefore reactor is supercritical.

Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. When keff = 0.955, ρ =-0.047 delta k/k; 4.9% delta k/k = + 0.049 delta k/k - 0.047 + 0.049 delta k/k = + 0.002 delta k/k, therefore reactor is supercritical.
Correct

Incorrect. REF: UWNR Operator Training Manual, Reactor Physics II. When keff = 0.955, ρ =-0.047 delta k/k; 4.9% delta k/k = + 0.049 delta k/k - 0.047 + 0.049 delta k/k = + 0.002 delta k/k, therefore reactor is supercritical.

question: Question 20-04/24/2012 A characteristic peculiar to TRIGA fuel is that it has a relatively large (and quickly acting):

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, pp. 112-114.
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, pp. 112-114.
Incorrect. REF: NEEP 234, pp. 112-114.
Correct
